hints.content: Start by understanding what a 'special position' is. A position (i, j) is special if mat[i][j] == 1 and all other elements in row i and column j are 0.
Consider how to iterate through the matrix. You will need to check each position (i, j) to see if it is a special position. This means you will likely use nested loops.
When checking if a position is special, remember that you need to verify both the row and the column. Think about how you can efficiently check if all other elements in row i and column j are 0.
You might want to keep track of the number of 1s in each row and each column. This will help you quickly determine if a position (i, j) can be special.
As you check each position, if you find that mat[i][j] == 1, you should check the counts of 1s in row i and column j. If both counts are 1, then (i, j) is a special position.
Consider edge cases, such as a matrix filled entirely with 0s or a matrix that is 1x1. How should your solution handle these cases?
Make sure to account for the constraints given: 1 <= m, n <= 100. This means your solution should be efficient enough to handle the maximum size of the matrix.
Think about the return value. You need to return the total count of special positions found in the matrix. Keep a counter that increments each time you find a special position.
Before finalizing your solution, test it with different configurations of the binary matrix to ensure it handles various scenarios correctly, including edge cases.

questionNotes: A position (i, j) is special if mat[i][j] == 1 and all other elements in row i and column j are 0.
Constraints: 1 <= m, n <= 100; mat[i][j] is either 0 or 1.
Be mindful of 0-indexing in the matrix.
Return the total count of special positions.
